Number: 1251.68216 Incorporating regular vines in estimation of distribution algorithms. 2013 Summary: This chapter presents the incorporation and use of regular vines into estimation of distribution algorithms for solving numerical optimization problems. Several kinds of statistical dependencies among continuous variables can be taken into account by using regular vines. This work presents a procedure for selecting the most important dependencies in EDAs by truncating regular vines. Moreover, this chapter also shows how the use of mutual information in the learning of graphical models implies a natural way of employing copula functions.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C15 group coloring; multigraph; upper bound serial article Li, Hao; Lai, Hong-Jian Number: 6109894 Group colorability of multigraphs. 2013 Summary: Let math1 be a multigraph with a fixed orientation math2 and let math3 be a group. Let math4 denote the set of all functions math5 . A multigraph math6 is math7 -colorable if and only if for every math8 , there exists a math9 -coloring math10 such that for every math11 (assumed to be directed from math12 to math13 ), math14 . We define the group chromatic number math15 to be the minimum integer math16 such that math17 is math18 -colorable for any group math19 of order math20 under the orientation math21 . In this paper, we investigate the properties of math22 for multigraphs and prove an analogue to Brooks’ Theorem.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 11F41 11F80 11R42 11R80 Hilbert modular forms; Hilbert modular surfaces; Picard modular surfaces; L-functions; meromorphic continuation; potential modularity serial article Virdol, Cristian Number: 6110185 The meromorphic continuation of the zeta function of a product of Hilbert and Picard modular surfaces over CM-fields. 2013 Summary: In this paper we prove in particular the meromorphic continuation to the entire complex plane of the zeta function of a product of a Hilbert modular surface and a Picard modular surface regarded over arbitrary CM-fields (see the end of the Introduction for more results regarding the meromorphic continuation of the zeta functions associated to products of Shimura curves, quaternionic Shimura surfaces and Picard modular surfaces). In order to obtain the meromorphic continuation we show the simultaneous potential modularity for an arbitrary finite number of math1 -adic representations associated to Hilbert modular forms and Picard modular surfaces.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} DE 00A08 00A09 00A35 07A10 book Beetz, Jürgen Number: 6110171 math1 . Mathematics for cave men. ( math2 . Mathematik für Höhlenmenschen.) 2013 Preliminary review / Publisher’s description: Mehr als die einfache Logik eines Frühmenschen brauchen Sie nicht, um die Grundzüge der Mathematik zu verstehen. Denn Sie treffen in diesem Buch viele einfache, fast gefühlsmäßig zu erfassende mathematische Prinzipien des täglichen Lebens. Deswegen kann der Autor bei seinem Versuch, die Mathematik “begreiflich” zu machen, in die Steinzeit zurückgehen – genauer gesagt: etwa in die Jungsteinzeit, 10.000 Jahre vor unserer Zeitrechnung. Ackerbau und Viehzucht hatten schon begonnen. Dort treffen Sie Eddi Einstein, den Denker und Rudi Radlos, den Erfinder – die Hauptakteure. Ein dritter Geselle ist Siggi Spökenkieker, der Druide und Seher. Siggi ist mit der Gabe der Präkognition gesegnet. So können wir Eddi, den Denker, mit Erkenntnissen ausstatten, die erst Jahrtausende später von bedeutenden Philosophen und Mathematikern erlangt worden waren. Die wahre Meisterin dieser Wissenschaftsdisziplin ist jedoch Wilhelmine Wicca. Sie war so klug wie die drei Kerle zusammen. Deshalb galt sie auch als Hexe – was damals ein Ehrentitel war – und als weise Frau.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 11 regularized theta lift; Katok-Sarnak formulas; Niebur-Poincaré series serial article Matthes, Roland Number: 6110176 Regularized theta lifts and Niebur-type Poincaré series on math1 -dimensional hyperbolic space. 2013 Summary: We study theta liftings from math2 to math3 and vice versa. The theta-lift is realized via an integral transform with a Siegel theta series as kernel function. Since this Siegel theta series fails to be square integrable it has to be regularized. The regularization is obtained by applying a suitable differential operator built from the Laplacian. The Siegel theta series is seen to be related to an automorphic Selberg kernel function on math4 and therefore the Selberg transform applies to compute the Fourier coefficients of the lift. This gives formulas of Katok-Sarnak type for Fourier coefficients of positive as well as for negative index, involving geodesic cycles. As an application we can lift Poincaré series of Niebur type. The lifted series are again Poincaré series built with Whittaker functions.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C70 05C38 05C76 math1 -path vertex cover; vertex cover; dissociation number; independence number; graph products serial article Jakovac, Marko; Taranenko, Andrej Number: 6109893 On the math2 -path vertex cover of some graph products. 2013 Summary: A subset math3 of vertices of a graph math4 is called a math5 -path vertex cover if every path of order math6 in math7 contains at least one vertex from math8 . Denote by math9 the minimum cardinality of a math10 -path vertex cover in math11 . In this paper, improved lower and upper bounds for math12 of the Cartesian and the strong product of paths are derived. It is shown that for math13 those bounds are tight. For the lexicographic product bounds are presented for math14 , moreover math15 and math16 are exactly determined for the lexicographic product of two arbitrary graphs. As a consequence the independence and the dissociation number of the lexicographic product are given.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 11 RSA; bit pattern; sparse integer serial article Meng, Xianmeng Number: 6110182 On RSA moduli with half of the bits prescribed. 2013 Summary: We give a probabilistic algorithm that constructs an RSA modulus math1 with prescribed bit patterns, where primes math2 and math3 are both of math4 -bit size. Assume the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis. We show that the algorithm can generate an RSA modulus math5 with the math6 least significant bits prescribed in advance, with time complexity of polynomial in math7 .

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 11 cubic fields; quartic fields; sextic fields; Pólya fields; integer-valued polynomials serial article Leriche, Amandine Number: 6110179 Cubic, quartic and sextic Pólya fields. 2013 Summary: A Pólya field is a number field math1 , with ring of integers math2 , such that the math3 -module formed by the integer-valued polynomials on math4 has a regular basis. We are interested here by Pólya fields of small degree. We give a complete characterization of cyclic cubic, quartic and sextic Pólya fields (quadratic Pólya fields are known for a long time). Moreover, we prove that, with few exceptions, the compositum of two quadratic Pólya fields is a biquadratic Pólya field. Finally, we study sextic Pólya fields which are the Galoisian closure of pure cubic fields.
